Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Lok-kun Tsui of the University of Virginia to conduct a research project, entitled "Storing sunlight in hydrogen with nanotube solar cells," during the summer of 2012 at Waseda University in Tokyo, Japan. The host scientist is Prof. Takayuki Homma.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project lies in a better understanding of the energy conversion performance in photoelectrochemical solar cells made from titanium dioxide nanotubes, sensitized to visible light with cuprous oxide and hematite. Specifically, the research objective of this project is to determine the correlation between the electronic structure, electrochemical and charge transport properties of these systems in order to design more efficient devices. This research has the potentail to advance U.S. energy independence by developing a way to produce storable solar energy in a scalable manner using low-cost materials and synthesis techniques. Further, it advances the fuel production stage needed for a future hydrogen economy. Understanding the properties of this titanium dioxide nanotube system and its surface modification can also move forward other technological applications including photocatalysis and sensors.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solar energy is the only energy resource capable of meeting the world’s energy needs, but the transient nature of sunlight demands that this energy be stored for it to become an economical, widely-adopted energy resource. Photoelectrochemical solar cells address this issue by using sunlight to split water into hydrogen and oxygen, with the hydrogen being stored and used as a fuel to generate electricity on demand. Titania (TiO2) nanotubes formed from anodizing titanium foils in fluoride containing electrolytes are a promising materials system for this application because of their high surface area, one-dimensional charge transport, and stability in solution and under irradiation. They are aligned arrays of cylindrical structures on the order of 100nm in width, and typically around 1 micron in length. Their absorption range can be extended from the UV into the visible range by the electrodeposition of visible light absorbers cuprous oxide (Cu2O) or hematite (Fe2O3).

                The goal of this project was to study the electronic and electrochemical structure of the TiO2 nanotubes and TiO2 nanotubes modified by Cu2O and Fe2O3 in collaboration primarily with Prof. Takayuki Homma of Waseda University in Tokyo, Japan. We determined that the crystallinity of the TiO2 nanotubes can be tuned by modifying the water content of the electrolytes, which ultimately allows us to optimize the efficiency of these nanotubes. A photocurrent conversion efficiency of 30% was obtained under low intensity UV light. Studies were also performed to measure the doping and flat band potential of TiO2 nanotubes modified by Cu2O and Fe2O3, parameters that enable us to construct a map of the electronic structure of their interfaces. This is a fundamental step to understand electrical transport and design optimized interfaces. Finally, measurement of UV-Visible reflectance spectra allowed us to determine at what wavelengths the addition of Cu2O and Fe2O3 extends the absorption of the TiO2 nanotube arrays.
